Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Patterns of Diversity and Endemism in South-East Asian scorpions: Systematics and Biogeography of Chaerilidae
Award.AbstractNarration:
The scorpion family Chaerilidae includes 43 species distributed across South and South-East Asia. Chaerilids are morphologically diverse and adapted to caves, leaf-litter and rocky habitats. They have restricted distributions and are often endemic to islands. The classification of these scorpions is in disarray and little is known about their evolution. The co-PI will revise Chaerilidae and investigate how they diversified across South-East Asia. This will require collecting chaerilid scorpions across their range, assessing variation within and between species, constructing an evolutionary tree for the family using DNA and morphological data, and mapping their distribution across South-East Asia. An NSF DDIG will allow the co-PI to collect chaerilid scorpions in Indonesia, where they have been poorly surveyed, and gather the data necessary to complete her dissertation.

South-East Asia has a geologically complex history and much remains to be understood about how organisms diversified across this region. This project will contribute to understanding of the geological history of Indonesia and the evolution of its fauna. The biota of Indonesia is also severely threatened by habitat destruction. Assessing the diversity of chaerilid scorpions will contribute to understanding the biodiversity of South-East Asia, important for making informed conservation decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Intellectual Merit The evolution and classification of many arthropod taxa is poorly understood due to a lack of expertise. Much of the arthropod diversity is concentrated in the world’s tropical and temperate rainforests, which are disappearing at an alarming rate due to human activities. The need to document the arthropod diversity of these ecosystems has never been more urgent. This project, which addresses the evolution of a little known group of arthropods, supported training in a field with few experts and enhanced understanding of diversification in the megadiverse, undersurveyed and highly endangered biota of tropical South and South-East Asia.

The scorpion family Chaerilidae includes 40 described species distributed across South and South-East Asia. Chaerilids are diverse and adapted to caves, leaf-litter and rocky habitats. The various species have restricted distributions and are often found endemic to particular islands or mountain ranges. The classification of these scorpions is in disarray and little is known about their evolution. Understanding their diversity is hampered by the small sample size and poor condition of material available for most species. Molecular data cannot be obtained without DNA-quality material and species limits cannot be adequately assessed without adults, especially males.

This project aimed to revise the species of Chaerilidae and present the first analysis of their evolutionary relationships, based on morphology and DNA sequences, to understand how they diversified across South and South-East Asia. This required collecting chaerilid scorpions across their range; assessing variation within and between species; constructing an evolutionary tree for the family; and mapping the known distributions of the species.

An NSF DDIG was integral to completing several objectives of the project. Fresh material of several species, including the first adult male and female specimens of some species not collected since the 1800s, was obtained during an expedition to the Indonesian islands of Java and Sumatra, the second most speciose country for Chaerilidae, encompassing the biogeographical regions of Sundaland and Wallacea. The first DNA sequences were generated from these Indonesian scorpions. Analyses of these data resulted in the discovery of new species and demonstrated a deep level of genetic diversity, suggesting that these scorpions, which represent an ancient lineage, are more diverse than previously thought.

 

Broader Impacts South-East Asia has a geologically complex history and much remains to be understood about how organisms diversified across this region. This project on the evolution and diversification of chaerilid scorpions contributed to understanding the geological history of the region and the evolution of its diverse fauna. The biota of Indonesia in particular is severely threatened by habitat destruction. Assessing the diversity of chaerilid scorpions contributes to understanding the biodiversity of South-East Asia, which is important for making informed decisions about areas to prioritize for conservation.
